node.title: As atmospheric rivers become more likely, so do floods
node.alt: The floodplains in Windsor, western Sydney with rugby goals in the foreground.
node.description: After a thoroughly soggy week, a new paper confirms this kind of thing is going to become more likely as the climate warms.
node.content:
["After a thoroughly soggy week, a new paper confirms\u00a0this kind of thing is expected\u00a0to become more likely as the climate warms.\u00a0", "What will this mean for low-lying areas and how do we make our communities more resilient to flooding?", "PhD student Kimberley Reid studies atmospheric\u00a0rivers,\u00a0a emotive name for a narrow region of strong water\u00a0vapour that streams through the atmosphere.\u00a0", "These atmospheric rivers allow moisture to flow around the world, and are often associated with heavy rain and floods.\u00a0", "Incidentally, this week's rain\u00a0is the result\u00a0of an atmospheric river but it's not the only one to have hit the country this year.", "There was also an atmospheric river during the devastating\u00a0flooding in Sydney and much of New South Wales in March.\u00a0", "", "
Kimberley Reid's research\u00a0shows\u00a0flooding like we have seen this week is going to become more common.(Supplied: Kimberley Reid)
", "In a\u00a0new peer-reviewed study, Ms Reid and her colleagues used climate models to see how frequent\u00a0events like the prolonged heavy rainfall and\u00a0flooding in Sydney,\u00a0would be under\u00a0moderate and high emissions scenarios.", "\"So we looked at events that had this long-term water-vapour transport, and found that these kinds of events were likely to occur about 80 per cent\u00a0more often by the end of the century, under both emissions scenarios.\"", "The moderate emissions scenario (SSP245 for any climate buffs out\u00a0there) is projected\u00a0to result in 2.5 to 3 degrees Celsius of warming\u00a0by 2100 and the high emissions scenario (SSP585)\u00a05 degrees of warming.\u00a0", "
Why would atmospheric rivers become more likely?\u00a0
", "According to Ms Reid, there is a pretty simple explanation for why atmospheric rivers and water-vapour transport would become more common in a warming climate.\u00a0", "", "
Maps show how the river of moisture decended upon eastern Australia back in March.\u00a0(Supplied: Kimberley Reid)
", "\"A\u00a0warm atmosphere can hold more water, so the chances of getting regions in the atmosphere with this high water-vapour content increases,\" she said.\u00a0", "It does not mean that all regions will see more rain, but overall flooding\u00a0is expected to\u00a0increase.", "Prior to COP26\u00a0Glasgow,\u00a0the UN warned the world was on track to warm by 2.7C by 2100 and a study from the Climate Action Tracker found, despite pledges made at COP26, the world was heading for 2.4C of warming by 2100.\u00a0", "It's a\u00a0concern for Ms Reid, as they put warming\u00a0very close to\u00a0the scenarios in her\u00a0study.\u00a0", "\"The main point is that we really need these COP pledges to turn into action if we want to avoid more of these kinds of events in the future,\" she warned.", "
Increased flooding\u00a0has long been linked to climate change
", "Hamish McGowan from the University of Queensland, not involved with the study, said\u00a0the new paper\u00a0reaffirmed\u00a0what had\u00a0been evident in the literature for some time now.", "\"That is, as temperatures warm, the atmosphere's water holding capacity increases and when it rains we get more rainfall,\" Professor McGowan\u00a0said.\u00a0", "", "
University of Queensland professor of atmospheric sciences Hamish McGowan.\u00a0(Supplied: Hamish McGowan)
", "\"Certainly, this paper makes a valuable contribution in bringing that into a local context\u00a0by focusing on the event in March in Sydney.\"", "As\u00a0we moved forward, he said, Australians needed to be conscious of the fact that\u00a0the climate was going to become more extreme.", "\"Residents generally need to be conscious of that, but also those who have responsibilities for planning and managing our urban infrastructure.", "\"That's something certainly which they need to take on board, in terms of how they plan our cities, in preparation for a future where climate and the hydrological system is going to become more variable and at times more extreme.\"", "
How do we cope with more flooding?\u00a0
", "According to Richard Thornton, CEO of\u00a0Natural Hazards Research Australia, if flooding becomes more frequent, it will cease to be a one-off and become something we need to prepare for more thoroughly.\u00a0", "", "
Richard Thornton is director of the Bushfire and Natural Hazards Co-operative Research Centre.(ABC News: Sean Warren)
", "He recommends checking in with your local council to see if you are in a flood zone, coming up with a plan for how you will respond in a flood and checking you are sufficiently insured.\u00a0", "He said\u00a0it was\u00a0almost a universal mantra for living in Australia these days. \u00a0", "\"Whether it's cyclones, floods, fires, earthquakes all of those things, we need to be more prepared for them because they'll happen one day.", "Dr Thornton said it we couldn't\u00a0contain climate change to something which we could\u00a0reasonably adapt\u00a0to, we might\u00a0need to think about a retreat from certain\u00a0areas where we currently live.", "Moving out of the flood zone is even a possibility, as demonstrated by moving the town of\u00a0Grantham after the 2011 Queensland floods.\u00a0", "\"We need to think in a really whole-of-community sense about how do we manage the retreat from some of these events,\" he said.\u00a0"]
